instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3209: What is 820-3209? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.3V42_G3H: What is 3V42_G3H? This is shorthand for PP3V42_G3H which is one of the first power rails that must turn on in older Macbooks that use a magsafe charger in order for them to get a light on the charger. This power rail powers the onewire circuit and the SMC, which are necessary for the machine to communicate with the charger and get it to turn on, as well as begin the bootup sequence. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.SMC_PM_G2_EN: What is SMC_PM_G2_EN? SMC_PM_G2_EN is a signal that comes from the SMC that is a prerequsite for all of the enable signals for the S5 rails to come on, such as P3V3S5_EN. S5 rails will not come on if SMC_PM_G2_EN is not coming..
definitions.SMC_ADAPTER_EN: What is SMC_ADAPTER_EN? SMC_ADAPTER_EN enables the machine to work off of the power adapter when the proper power adapter is attached. Attacching an 85w Macbook Pro 15” power adapter to a 13” Macbook that requires a 60w power adapter is ok, attaching a 45w Macbook Air power adapter to a 15” macbook Pro that needs an 85w power adapter will result in SMC_ADAPTER_EN missing. .
definitions.PM_DSW_PWRGD: What is PM_DSW_PWRGD? The "PM_DSW_PWRGD" signal in a MacBook stands for "Deep Sleep Well Power Good” and is required for the machine to power on & post..
definitions.PCH_DSWVRMEN:
What is PCH_DSWVRMEN? DSWVRMEN stands for DeepSx Well On-Die Voltage Regulator Enable. This signal enables the internal DSW 1.05 V regulators and must be always pulled-up to PPVRTC_G3H 3.3 volts.
If this signal is not being asserted (i.e., not enabled), the on-die voltage regulators responsible for supplying power in deep sleep states may not be active. This could lead to the MacBook failing to exit from a deep sleep state or having issues when trying to enter one, contributing to a scenario where the device does not power on.

If the signal is not present or not at the correct levels, it could indicate a problem with the Platform Controller Hub (PCH) itself..
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.RTC_RESET_L: What is RTC_RESET_L? RTC_RESET_L is a reset signal that is present when the signal is low, the _L means it is asserted when the voltage is low. The RESET signal will keep the PCH from turning on or booting up the machine. .
definitions.PCH_SRTCRST_L: What is PCH_SRTCRST_L? PCH_SRTCRST_L is a reset signal present for the RTC circuit that asserts when it is low in voltage, that is what _L means..
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF: What is SMC_ONOFF? SMC_ONOFF is a signal that tells the machine that the power button has been pressed so it knows to turn on, or turn off. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
Hello, my customer brught me a Macbook <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1466</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which has a board number <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.

I have changed the all parts which had corrosion. And we have bought a new I/O board for the device. When we put the board into the case and connect everything we saw that the fan starts for a second then goes off and device too.

Then we took the board out from the case and put the charger on again under the thermal camera, and found out that <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> is flashing under the thermal. 

Thought that it might be charger problem and tried another one but the problem is still same. 

Any ideas about what it could be ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
You didn't mentione any board voltage, or signal.
No idea if you get Magsafe light at least.

To discard <TRANSISTOR>Q7080</TRANSISTOR> leakage, test the board using lab PSU, or fake charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
First of all sorry for the empty post.

I get orange magsafe light on for a while then in 3 or 4 seconds it goes slowly down. I found out that on <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR> I can read the 8.4V on 1st and 2nd leg. But on other legs the voltage jumps from 0.00 to different voltages on each leg.

I dont know where else I need to start to  look at it to be honest.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
No idea how did you arrive to <TRANSISTOR>Q7630</TRANSISTOR>.

What about <SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage at F7040 (without battery connected)?
Check when Magsafe light disappears too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
As Im always saying that Im a learner. I have found out that I forgot the put the flex cable from I/O board to mainboard. Now the magsafe lights are on always and it is orange. 

 <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> = 8.39V
<SIGNAL>3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.43V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
Post <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS, <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> and the 4 PCH's RTC (DC) signals.
If all present, trigger <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> and check for drop pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
I couldn't find the  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS  line and is 4PCH's RTC signals are from:

<SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVOUT_G3_PCH_DCPRTC</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>RTC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PCH_SRTCRST_L</SIGNAL> these ones you want me to check signals as 4 PCH's RTC?

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> = 3.33V
<SIGNAL>SMC_PM_G2_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.43V
<SIGNAL>SMC_ADAPTER_EN</SIGNAL> = 3.4V
<SIGNAL>PM_DSW_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 3.43V
<SIGNAL>PCH_DSWVRMEN</SIGNAL> = 3.32V

And normally I have 3.4V steady on  <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> but when we trigger  <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL>  it goes down to 0.35V and stays there. When we leave it it goes back to 3.4V again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
"I couldn't find the  <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL>/SUS  line"
Of course, there is no LINE; I mentioned two LINES.
We use such notation since years here; guess what means, please.

If you detected the drop pulse on <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL>, then check for pulse at <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>, at same time.
Use <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> pads to simulate power button, not keeping the line down.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on this line without trigger way there is always a pulse from 0.00V to 3.4V but nothing effecting when we trigger the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF</SIGNAL>
<SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> =3.3V
<SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> = 3.3V too

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> pulsing every 5s, or how.
When it pulse, you should also catch a pulse at 5V coil, at least.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message: I catched it from L5750 and yes it is definitely every 5 sec goes up to 5V and back to around 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
Then check if other big coils pulse in same manner.
I was thinking about L7270.
L5750 receives <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, so you should get pulse on many more coils.
Pay atention to L7510/50.

Check what happens in SMC bypass mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
I got no V on L7510 and L7550 if you meant so and unfortunately I can't see any L7270 on the boardview.
I think you meant L7220 it is same with L5750 pulse 5V every 5 sec

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
Sorry, L7220...

So no pulse at all at CPU coils?
Check all other coils...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3209</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Turn On Problem After Liquid Spilled
threads.message:
No pulse on L7630
Pulse on L7330
Pulse on L7100
Pulse on L7030
pulse between 1V - 2V on L3895
Pulse on L7720
Pulse between 3V - 4.8V on L4605

threads.message: Please dont be mad with me :) What is smc bypass mode and how can I do it?
